<body>

<h1>Dr. B.R. Ambedkar</h1>
 <div class="a" >- Former Minister of Law and Justice of India.</div>


<div class="image"><img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Dr._Bhimrao_Ambedkar.jpg/1200px-Dr._Bhimrao_Ambedkar.jpg"></div>

<div class="quote">
<pre>
      "If I find the constitution being misused, I shall be the first to burn it.”
               
       ― Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar


</pre>
</div>

<div class="about">
Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar BR was an Indian jurist, economist, social reformer and political leader who <b>headed the committee drafting the Constitution of India</b> from the Constituent Assembly debates, served as Law and Justice minister in the first cabinet of Jawaharlal Nehru, and inspired the Dalit Buddhist movement after renouncing Hinduism.
</div>

<table>

<tr>
<td><b>Born</b></td>
<td>14 April 1891 Central India Agency, British India (Madhya Pradesh, India)</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b>Died</b></td>
<td>6 December 1956 (aged 65) New Delhi, India</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b>Resting Place</b></td>
<td>Chaitya Bhoomi, Mumbai, India</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b>Political Party</b></td>
<td>Independent Labour Party and Scheduled Castes Federation</td>
</tr>

</table>

<div class="quo"><img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"></div>
<div class="info">
<p>Birth and Childhood</p>
<ul>
<li>B R Ambedkar was born on 14 April, 1891 in Mhow, Madhya Pradesh.</li>
<li>His father’s name was Ramji Maloji Sakpal. He was a Subedar in the Indian Army
and posted at Mhow cantonment, Madhya Pradesh.</li>
<li>B R Ambedkar’s father was a strict and pious man. He believed in the importance
of education, and made sure that all his children enrolled in the Army schools.
Along with his children, he often sang devotional songs composed by Namdev,
Tukaram, Moropant and Mukteshwar, and read stories from the Ramayana and
the Mahabharata. </li>
<li>Ambedkar’s mother’s name was Bhimabai Murbadkar Sakpal. B R Ambedkar was
the fourteenth and last child of his parents.</li>
<li>His family was of Marathi background from the town of Ambavade, in the
Ratnagiri district of modern-day Maharashtra. His family was economically
disadvantaged and since they belonged to a backward caste, they were subjected
to socio-economic discrimination</li>
<li>Ramji Sakpal retired in 1894 and the family moved to Satara two years later.
Shortly after their move, Ambedkar's mother died. The children were cared for by
their paternal aunt Meerabai, and lived in difficult circumstances. After a while, his
father remarried and the family shifted to Mumbai.</li>

</ul>

<p>Early Education</p>
<ul>
<li>Both Ambedkar's father and grandfather worked with the army of the British
East India Company. This ensured a good education for Ambedkar in the
army-run schools. Education would have otherwise been denied to him by the
virtue of his caste.</li>
<li>Although able to attend the Army School, Ambedkar and other children from
similar backward castes, were not allowed to sit inside the class and given little
attention or assistance by the teachers. Ambedkar was required to sit on a
gunny sack which he had to take home with himself.</li>
<li>Even if they needed to drink water, someone from a higher caste would have to
pour that water from a height as they were not allowed to touch either the
water or the vessel that contained it.</li>
<li>Bhimrao was an average student. When many of his classmates left for good
jobs in Bombay, he too longed to be independent. He realized that if he ever
were to be successful, he would have to concentrate more on his studies.</li>
<li>In 1897, Ambedkar's family moved to Mumbai. Ambedkar became the only
student from a backward caste, to enroll at the Elphinstone High School.
Even there, he had to face caste prejudice and discrimination. </li>
<li>In 1906, his marriage was arranged with nine-year-old Ramabai.
Ambedkar passed his matriculation examination in 1907.</li>
<li>The following year he entered Elphinstone College, which was affiliated to the
University of Bombay, becoming the first from his community to do so.</li>
</ul>


<p>Higher Education</p>
<ul>
<li>By 1912, he obtained his degree in economics and political science from Bombay
University, and prepared to take up employment with the Baroda state
government. Very soon however, he had to return to Mumbai to see his ailing
father, who died on 2 February, 1913. </li>
<li>The same year, he was awarded a Baroda State Scholarship by the Gaekwad of
Baroda – Sayaji Rao III, and Ambedkar went to Columbia University in America,
for his post-graduate education. </li>
<li>From America, Ambedkar proceeded to London to study economics and political
science. In 1917, his scholarship came to an end and the Baroda government
called him back. The Maharaja of Baroda appointed Ambedkar as his ‘Defense
Secretary’. </li>
<li>Ambedkar returned to Bombay in November 1917. He tried to earn his living as a
private tutor and an accountant. He even started his own consultancy, which
failed because people would not give him any work because of his caste. Finally,
Ambedkar began working as a Professor of Political Economics at the Sydenham
College of Commerce and Economics.</li>
<li>In September 1920, after accumulating sufficient funds, Ambedkar went back to
London to complete his studies. He completed his Masters in Economics in 1921
and became a barrister and got a Doctorate in Science in 1923. In 1927, he was
awarded a PhD from the Columbia University in America.</li>

</ul>

<section class="packages">
<div>
<figure>
<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,">

</figure>

<figure>

<figcaption><b>Dr. Ambedkar as a barrister</b></figcaption>
</figure>

<figure>
<img src="https://gandhifoundation.files.wordpress.com/2015/01/dr-ambedkar.jpg">
<figcaption><b>Dr. Ambedkar speaking at an event</b></figcaption>
</figure>
</div>

</section>


<p>Work and Political Career</p>
<ul>
<li>Upon returning to India, Ambedkar started practicing law at the Bombay High
Court. Side by side, he continued working for the upliftment of the backward
castes. His first organized attempt to achieve this was the creation of the
‘Bahishkrit Hitakarini Sabha’ in 1924.</li>
<li>In 1932, British announced the formation of separate election mechanism for
the backward castes. While Ambedkar was in favour of the same, Gandhiji
opposed it saying that such an arrangement would divide the Hindu community
into two groups. On 25 September 1932, an agreement known as ‘Poona Pact’
was signed between Ambedkar (on behalf of the backward castes among
Hindus) and Madan Mohan Malaviya (on behalf of the other Hindus)</li>
<li> In 1936, Ambedkar founded the ‘Independent Labour Party’, which contested in
the 1937 Bombay election to the Central Legislative Assembly for the 13
reserved and 4 general seats and securing 11 and 3 seats respectively.</li>
<li>Ambedkar transformed his political party into the ‘All-India Scheduled Castes
Federation’ and in 1946, participated in the elections held for the ‘Constituent
Assembly of India’. However, they could not perform very well</li>
<li>Upon India's independence on 15 August 1947, the new Congress-led
government invited Ambedkar to serve as the nation's first Law Minister, which
he accepted. On 29 August, he was appointed Chairman of the Constitution
Drafting Committee and charged by the Constituent Assembly to write India's
new Constitution</li>
<li>In November 1948, the Draft Constitution with its 315 articles and 8 schedules
was formally introduced to the Constituent Assembly. In November 1949, the
Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution.</li>
<li>Ambedkar resigned from the cabinet in 1951 and contested an election
independently to the Lok Sabaha, in 1952. He was however defeated in the
Bombay (North Central) constituency by a little-known Narayan Sadoba Kajrolkar.
He was appointed to the Rajya Sabha in March 1952.</li>
</ul>



<p>Death and Legacy
</p>
<ul>
<li>In 1956, from June to October, Ambedkar was bedridden at his Delhi residence.
His eyes were failing and he suffered from the side effects of the drugs he was
given for his diabetes. On 6 December 1956, Dr. B R Ambedkar passed away
at his home in Delhi.</li>
<li>A memorial for Dr. Ambedkar was established at his Delhi house at 26 Alipur
Road. His birthdate is celebrated as a public holiday known as ‘Ambedkar
Jayanti’ or ‘Bhim Jayanti’. </li>
<li>Dr. B R Ambedkar is looked upon as one of the greatest political leaders of our
country. He dedicated his life to the upliftment of the backward castes.
As a recognition of his efforts in the making of our Constitution, he is known as
the ‘Architect of the Indian Constitution’.</li>
<li>In order to mark his tremendous contribution to the Indian nation, in 1990,
Dr. B R Ambedkar was posthumously awarded India's highest civilian honour,
the Bharat Ratna.</li>

</ul>

</div>
<br>

<div class="timeline">
<p class="time">Important Life Events</p>
<ul>
<li><span>1891 </span>Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar born at Mahu in Madhya Pradesh.</li>
<li><span>1907 </span>Married to nine year old Ramabai.</li>
<li><span>1907 </span>Passed matriculation examination from Elphinstone High School, Bombay.</li>
<li><span>1912 </span>Passed B. A. from Elphinstone College, Bombay.</li>
<li><span>1913 </span>Leaves for the U.S.A. to join Columbia University, New York.</li>
<li><span>1915 </span>Awarded M.A. degree in Economics.</li>
<li><span>1918 </span>Teaches at Syndenham College of Commerce & Economics, Bombay.</li>
<li><span>1920 </span>Leaves for London to complete his studies.</li>
<li><span>1921 </span>Awarded M. S. degree</li>
<li><span>1923 </span>Awarded D.Sc. Degree & called to the Bar</li>
<li><span>1924 </span>Starts legal practice at the Bombay High Court.</li>
<li><span>1926 </span>Nominated member of Bombay Legislative Council; served till 1934</li>
<li><span>1928 </span>Appointed lecturer at Government Law College, Bombay.</li>
<li><span>1930 </span>Starts Kalaram Temple Entry Satyagraha at Nashik.</li>
<li><span>1930 </span>Attends three Round Table Conferences</li>
<li><span>1933 </span>Gandhiji – Ambedkar meeting at Yeravda Jail.</li>
<li><span>1935 </span>Wife Ramabai dies.</li>
<li><span>1935 </span>Appointed Principal in Government Law College.</li>

<li><span>1937 </span>Elected to the Bombay Provincial Legislative Assembly</li>
<li><span>1937 </span>Floats a new political party, the Independent Labour Party</li>

<li><span>1942 </span>Appointed as Labour Minister.</li>
<li><span>1945 </span>Starts People ‘ s Education Society.</li>
<li><span>1947 </span>Nominated to the Constituent Assembly by the Indian National Congress.</li>
<li><span>1947 </span>Constituent Assembly appoints a Drafting Committee with Ambedkar as Chairman. </li>
<li><span>1949 </span>Presents the Draft Constitution in the Constituent Assembly and Accepted Indian Constitution.</li>
<li><span>1952 </span>The Columbia University conferred the honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws.</li>
<li><span>1956 </span>Embraced Buddhism at Nagpur and Leaves for Kathmandu for 4th World Buddhist Conference</li>
<li><span>1956 </span>Dies in sleep at Delhi.</li>
<li><span>1990 </span>Awarded the Bharat Ratna Award. </li>


</ul>
</div>


<div class="last">
“Cultivation of mind should be the ultimate aim of human existence”

</div>







</body>
</html>
